--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Rusty Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> =
...
> @BeforeTest/@BeforeSuite is more descriptive than @Before/@BeforeClas=
s. 
> I prefer it. I might want to go even further and change @Before to 
>=
 @BeforeEachTest but maybe that's going to far.
> 
> 
> On the flip side, @=
Before is easier to type than @BeforeClass. This 
> means programmers are m=
ore likely to use it, which is more likely to be 
> correct. I'm afraid if =
we change @Before to @BeforeTest then a lot of 
> code will end up in @Befo=
reClass/@BeforeSuite that doesn't belong there.
> ...

Thank you for your r=
eply, 
You're right, it is easier to type, but this doesn't compensate the
=
lack of clarity in my opinion. Plus, you normally don't write more
than one=
 @BeforeTest method per class. I also think(hope) that most
programmers cho=
ose the modules they use depending on what those
modules do, not on how lon=
g their names are... The shorter names may
also be the cause of misundersta=
ndings (since they are less clear)
which can result in code being put into =
places where it doesn't belong.
